loans.name: Perlita Group

texts.en:
Perlita is 54 years old and lives in Segatic Daku, Osamiz City. She is married with three children. Perlita has a general store business and earns approximately 3,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) each month doing this type of work. She has a requested loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase canned goods, a sack of rice, noodles, etc. Perlita has been a member of PMPC for three months. In the future, Perlita hopes to be successful in her chosen business. 

Perlita is the leader of a four-person group. Although they borrow as a group, each member of the group has her own business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock for her business.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en: Arlene is 47 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children. Arlene has a shop that sells viands (dishes) like afritada, caldereta, pancit bihon and roasted chickens. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan for 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to buy raw ingredients for making viands and roasted chickens. Arlene has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Arlene hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making viands (dishes) and roasted chickens.

loans.name: Lenibeth

texts.en:
Lenibeth is 44 years of age with one child, living in DCM, Mahayag, Zamboanga del Sur. She has a hypo [calcium hypochlorite, a disinfectant] business in their barangay [village]. She has had this business for more than one year. She requested a loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos to purchase gallons of hypochlorite for her retail business.

Lenibeth has been a member of Paglaum Multi-purpose Cooperative for almost two years. In the future, Lenibeth hopes that she can provide for the needs of her family and improve their daily living.

loans.use: to purchase gallons of hypochlorite for her retail business

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 36 years old, married, and a mother of three. She runs a retail business selling shoes, clothes, utensils, cosmetics, and buckets. She has operated the business for six years.  Previously, she was operating a tailoring business.

Margaret appreciates Faulu Kenya for helping her to improve her business. This has helped her to become more financially stable.  

She has requested 60,000 Kenya shillings to add stock of shoes, clothes, utensils, and cosmetics.

loans.use: to add stock of shoes, clothes, utensils, and cosmetics.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 33 years old. He lives with his pensioner parents and his wife in Ijevan City.

Since 1996, Robert has been engaged in a clothes trading business with his mother. He rents a stall in the clothes market in Ijevan City. Robert buys clothes in wholesale markets in Yerevan and resells them in his stall in Ijevan City. He sells only men's clothes: suits, trousers, sweaters, and tracksuits. 

This is Robert's second loan from Kiva and third from Nor Horizon. Thanks to his first Kiva loan, Robert increased his business merchandise assortment and made a good profit, which allowed him to buy furniture for his house.
 
Now Robert is seeking a loan of 1,000,000 Armenian dram to buy winter clothes for Christmas and New Year resale.

loans.use: to buy winter clothes for Christmas and New Year resale.

loans.name: Rodel

texts.en:
This is Rodel, 42, resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Rosanna, a housewife and mother to their three children. Rodel, together with his wife and children, manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, he is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Rodel operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal in the local neighbourhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 pesos' worth of cooking oil or an egg. Rodel makes profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. His store is located adjacent to his house. His regular customers are his neighbours and the local community. He earns a minimum of 500 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help him continue the operation of his business, he is requesting a 29,000 PHP loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand his product inventory. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business.

Rodel hopes to be able to expand soon, just as he hopes to send all his children to college to have a good future. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in his business.

loans.name: Willy

texts.en:
For the past four years, Willy has been working hard to manage his retail shop which sells soap, sugar and cooking oil. Willy is 34 years old and lives in the town of Kyenjojo in the Mubende region of Uganda. He is married and has three children with two of them currently in school. 

To help expand his business, Willy has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase food for resale and will help Willy to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Willy hopes that in the future he will be able to expand his business. 

Willy is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves microentrepreneurs like Willy, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase food for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Tabita Group

texts.en:
Tabita is 50 years old and lives in Segatic Daku, Osamiz City. She is married and has two children. Tabita has a general store and earns approximately 3,000 PHP each month doing this work. She has requested a loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase canned goods, a sack of rice, noodles, etc. Tabita has been a member of PMPC for five months. In the future, Tabita hopes to be successful in her chosen business. 

Tabita is the leader of a four-person group. Although they borrow as a group, each member of the group has her own business.

loans.use: to purchase inventory for her general store

loans.name: Enock

texts.en:
Enock is 43 years old and lives in the town of Kyenjojo in the Mubende region of Uganda. He is married and has four children, three of whom are currently in school. For the past three years, Enock has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells soap, sugar, and cooking oil. 

To help expand his business, Enock has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more soap, sugar, and cooking oil for resale. It will help Enock to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Enock hopes that in the future he will be able to expand his business more. 

Enock is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Enock who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase soap, sugar, and cooking oil for resale

loans.name: Katlyn

texts.en:
This is Katlyn, 28, resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. She is a single mother with one child. By the grace of God, she has managed to support her child’s schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her child all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Katlyn, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Katlyn operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal in the local neighbourhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 pesos' worth of cooking oil or an egg. She makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbours and the local community. She earns a minimum of 400 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a 10,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Katlyn hopes to be able to expand soon and dreams of giving her child a good future. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Glenda

texts.en:
Glenda, age 39, lives in Banigan, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. To earn a living, Glenda buys and sells rice. She earns about PhP 5,000 every three months doing this work. She and her husband have one child.  

Glenda has requested a loan in the amount of PhP 3,000 to purchase rice to offer for sale. She is a new member of PMPC. In the future, Glenda would like to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy rice to offer for sale

loans.name: Abigumira

texts.en:
Abigumira, age 40, lives in the town of Kyenjojo in the Mubende region of Uganda. He and his wife have four children who are all currently enrolled in school. For the past three years, Abigumira has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells soap, sugar, and cooking oil. 

To help expand his business, Abigumira has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more soap, sugar, and cooking oil to offer for sale, and the expected profits will help Abigumira to improve his business and pay school fees for his children. Abigumira hopes that in the future he will be able to expand his business more. 

Abigumira is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Abigumira who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more soap, sugar, and cooking oil to offer for sale

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna, age 30, works in the fish industry, catching and selling fish to earn a living. She has been doing this for five years. She and her husband live in Malintuboan, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte with their two children.

She has requested a loan in the amount of PhP 20,000 in order to purchase a fishing boat.
 
Edna has been a member of PMPC for more than a year. In the future, Edna hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase a fishing boat

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher, age 40, is a farmer who demonstrates both humility and pride in his work. He has been planting and harvesting his cornfield for almost 15 years. Christopher and his wife have two children, and he is temporarily filling the role of both father and mother to his children because his wife is an OFW (Overseas Filipino Worker). 

Christopher reports difficulties in managing his cornfield because he doesn't have enough financial resources due to the family's daily household expenses, allowances, and the school fees of his children. 

Christopher currently has no choice but to get his farm inputs from traders who charge high interest rates because his field is far from the market. Christopher has decided to borrow additional capital in the amount of PhP 27,000 in order to improve his cornfield by buying farm inputs from traders who offer lower interest rates. 

He intends to use the expected profits to improve his family's standard of living and to support his children in their studies.

loans.use: to improve his cornfield by buying farm inputs

loans.name: Paulo

texts.en:
Paulo, age 27, has spent two years working hard to manage his retail shop business, which sells spare parts. He lives with his wife and child in the town of Mityana in the Mubende region of Uganda. 
 
To help expand his business, Paulo has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy spare parts for his shop, and this will help Paulo to generate greater profits, with which he intends to pay medical expenses, buy land, and build a house. Paulo hopes that in the future he will be able to expand his business more. 

Paulo is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Paulo who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for resale

loans.name: Cornelio

texts.en:
Cornelio is 63 years old, widowed, and has four adult children. He is from the city of Pantaon Ozamis City. To make a living, Cornelio raises crops. His main source of income comes from planting and harvesting root crops and bananas to sell. Cornelio has been engaged in his business for more than 20 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

Cornelio joined GDMPC in 2008 to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. Cornelio is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This will be Cornelio's third loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated with this loan to improve the general living conditions of his family.

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase banana fertilizer

loans.name: Mathias

texts.en:
Mathias is 43 years old and lives in the town of Mityana in the Mubende region of Uganda. He is married and has four children who are all currently in school. For the past three years, Mathias has been working hard to manage his retail shop in which he sells bags and clothes. 

To help expand his business, Mathias has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy clothes and bags for resale, and will help Mathias to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Mathias hopes that in the future, he will be able to expand his business more. 

Mathias is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Mathias who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy clothes and bags for resale.

loans.name: Juanalyn

texts.en:
Juanalyn lives in the village of Libag Sur. It is a 30-minute ride to reach grocery stores in the city proper. She is 34 years old and has three children, ages 12, 11 and 5. Her family lives less fortunately, but she is very happy to have them and they serve as her strength in times of weaknesses. 

With a starting capital of 6,000 Philippines pesos (P), Juanalyn grabbed the opportunity to establish a store in their place of residence. She patiently sells grocery items such as sardines, coffee, milk, sugars, shampoo, soap and detergents. She had been operating this for almost three years. 

Currently, she has inadequate funds, so she is asking a loan amount of P25,000 in order to diversify her business. She will use the loan to buy canned goods, soft drinks and biscuits to increase sales capacity in her store.

In the future, Juanalyn would like to continuously generate a good income and grow as a successful entrepreneur.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, soft drinks and biscuits to sell in her store.

loans.name: Tadeo

texts.en:
Tadeo is 30 years old and lives in the town of Mityana in the Mubende region of Uganda. He is single and has one child. For the past three years, Tadeo has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells phone accessories. 

To help expand his business, Tadeo has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more phone accessories for resale, and will help Tadeo generate greater profits to pay medical expenses, buy land, and build a house. Tadeo hopes that in the future he will be able to expand his business further. 

Tadeo is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Tadeo who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more phone accessories for resale.

loans.name: Charita

texts.en:
Charita is 45 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has seven children. 

Charita has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She has had this business for five years. She has requested a loan of PHP 4,000 to buy more canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

Charita is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Charita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

loans.name: Noly

texts.en:
Noly strives hard to improve his living conditions. He is 40 and is married, with three children. He is a farmer, and plants three hectares. Noly is able to earn about PHP 5,000 per cropping season. The income generated goes immediately to the family's daily needs, and the allowances and school fees of the children. 

Noly is thankful because his wife helps him in cultivating their corn field. The couple wants to send their children into higher level of education, since they didn't finished their studies. Noly has been doing his part as father to earn a living. 

Noly is requesting a loan of PHP 27,000 to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and herbicides, and to pay for labor and preparation of his farm land. He hopes that he will receive his requested loan so that he can use it wisely for the future of his children and the improvement of their living conditions.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, and herbicides, and to pay for labor and preparation of his farm land.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles is 27 years old. He is married and has two children, who live in his own house with four family members in Karuguuza, Uganda. His goal is to have a self-sustaining family. He has been in the business of buying and selling cattle for three years. He faces the challenge of inflation in the Ugandan market today. His dream is to own a ranch. Charles needs a loan to buy cattle for resale.

loans.use: to buy cattle.

loans.name: Shok

texts.en:
Shok is a 19-year-old bachelorette from Kfar Kanaaa. In June, she opened a centrally located clothing boutique. The boutique serves Kfar Kanaa, Nazareth and the surrounding villages. Shok has focused her stock on the 15 to 45-year-old age group providing up-to-date styles. She has already gained a strong clientele.

Shok needs this loan to purchase additional stock and specialty wear for the holiday season.

Shok wants to continue to expand her store, gain business experience and one day have staff who assist her in creating an exclusive clothing boutique.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock and specialty wear for the holiday season.

loans.name: Jurenda

texts.en:
Jurenda is 27 years old. She lives in Sudlon, Molave, Zamboanga del Sur. She is widowed, with three children.

Jurenda has a store that sells different types of products. She has had this business for two years. She is requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 to buy more stock for her general store.

Jurenda has been a member of PMPC for two years. In the future, Jurenda hopes to become a successful businesswoman, and to help her children finish their studies with the support of her business.

loans.use: to buy more stock for her general store.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is 29 years old and lives in the town of Kyenjojo in the Mubende region of Uganda. She is married and has three children with two of them currently in school. For the past six years, Irene has been working hard to manage her health clinic, which sells medicine. 

To help expand her business, Irene has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more medicine for resale and will help Irene to generate greater profits and pay the school fees for her children. Irene hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business. 

Irene is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Irene who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more medicine for resale

loans.name: Spencer

texts.en:
Spencer is 38 years old and is married with three children aged 6-13. They are living in their own semi-permanent house in Katikara, Uganda. His goal is to build a permanent house for his family and to educate his children.

Spencer is a hard-working man and for the last five years he has been operating a produce business. He started by farming and then saved to start the business, but he faces a challenge of poor roads and high inflation. He is requesting a loan to buy maize to sell.

loans.use: to buy maize to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow for his secondary business which is dairy farming

loans.name: Anatoli

texts.en:
Anatoli is married with eight children aged 2-16, living in his own house in Karuguuza, Uganda. His goal is to educate his children up to the university level.

Anatoli has been running a cattle buying and selling business for the past eight years. He started by purchasing one cow at a time and now he has the capacity to purchase up to four cows at once. He faces a challenge of price fluctuation and hopes that his business will, in the future, have enough capital to purchase at least ten cows. He is requesting a loan to buy more cattle to sell.

loans.use: to buy cattle to sell

loans.name: Larent

texts.en:
Larent is 29 years old and lives in the town of Kyenjojo in the Mubende region of Uganda. He is married and has one child. For the past two years, Larent has been working hard to manage his boutique shop, which sells clothes. 

To help expand his business, Larent has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes for resale and will help Larent generate greater profits and pay medical expenses. Larent hopes that in the future he will be able to expand his business more. 

Larent is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Larent who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase for more clothes for resale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary has been practicing farming in Ndunyu Njeru for the last 27 years. She is 50 years old and is married to Ng'ang'a, with whom she has two school going children.  

She was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers and this will be her fourth loan.  She paid all her previous loans well and in good time. She plans to use the loan to buy a dairy cow as well as for labor purposes in her farm where she plants crops.

In the future, Mary hopes to expand her farming business and increase her income and improve the living standards of her family.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy maize and groundnuts.

loans.name: Raul

texts.en:
Raul is 39 years old and married. He has been blessed with five children who are currently studying. Raul has been managing his cornfield for almost 20 years. He has noticed that half of his income goes to traders from whom he gets his farm supplies. So, for these reasons, Raul has insufficient funds to sustain their daily household expenses, allowances and school fees of his children. 

Raul said that he could only increase his yields and income if he borrows additional capital. In this regard, he is asking for financial assistance amounting to PHP 27,000, which he will use for the labor cost of land preparation and transplanting and for buying farm supplies needed to improve his agricultural business. In this way, he can uplift their living situation and send his children into a higher level of education.

loans.use: to be used for labor cost of land preparation and transplanting and for buying farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy sticky rice, sugar and plastic wrap.

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie is married with three children. Rosalie is 35 years old and lives in Mahayag, Zamboanga del Sur.

Rosalie has had a business printing items like t-shirts and IDs for eight years. She has requested a loan of PHP 25,000 to purchase materials and equipment for her printing business.

Rosalie became a member of PMPC recently. In the future, Rosalie hopes to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase materials and equipment for her printing business

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is a 43-year-old businessman who runs a butchery.  He has been in the business for eight years. He has employed two people to assist him in the business. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, his business has really improved because of his previous loans.

Francis hopes to become the major supplier of meat in his local area. He needs 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy meat and to renovate his butcher shop.

loans.use: To buy meat and to renovate his butcher shop

loans.name: Bunjojo Sacco Group

texts.en: John is a 48-year-old married man with four children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He sells fresh fruit, especially yellow bananas. He began with five bunches of bananas, but now he sells 106 bunches a week. His dream is to educate his children and expand his business. The challenge he faces is the high prices of the fruit. John needs the loan to buy fresh fruit to sell.

loans.use: to buy fresh fruits to sell

loans.name: Mirasol

texts.en:
Raising hogs is the primary source of income for Mirasol and her family. She raises hogs to fatten and breed and to sell to butchers who come into the village. Mirasol had been in this business for almost 10 years and usually gains a profit of PHP 10,000 monthly. 

Mirasol is 37 years old, married, and had two children to educate. She is now asking for a loan of PHP 20,000 to buy livestock feed, vitamins, and medicines for her hogs to ensure their good nutrition.

She would like to ensure the proper growth of her hogs so she can get a higher price for them. In the future, Mirasol wants to make her family more economically stable.

loans.use: to buy livestock feed, vitamins, and medicines for her hogs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a motorcycle for her transport business.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en: Delia is widowed with five children. She is 61 years old and lives in Cangmalalag, Larena, Siquijor. Delia is a dressmaker and earns approximately PHP 2,500 each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase assorted fabric for her dressmaking business. Delia has been a member of Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative for one year.  Delia hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fabric for her dressmaking business

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet is 26 years old and lives in Masindi, Uganda. She is a single mother who desires to have a boutique. Juliet earned money from working at a bakery and used it to buy clothes to sell. Currently she is a market vendor whose major challenge is limited capital and rain. She wants a loan to buy clothes for resell.

loans.use: to buy clothes to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy his own motorcycle for transport.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is 48 years old and lives in South Poblacion, Larena, Siquijor. She is married with one child. To earn a living, Gina has a local food stall. She earns about PHP 3,000 each month doing this type of work. Gina has a requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase assorted ingredients for her business.
Gina has been a member of Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative for ten months. In the future, Gina hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase assorted ingredients for her food stall

loans.name: Cheryl

texts.en: Cheryl is 35 years old and lives in Catulayan, San Juan, Siquijor. She is married with four children. Cheryl engages in selling fresh fish to earn a living. Each month, she earns PHP 6,000 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 to purchase fish to sell. Cheryl has been a member of the Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative for one month. Cheryl would like to have savings deposits for her children's future education.

loans.use: to purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: Francis is a 30-year-old married man who is blessed with a five-year-old child.  To earn a living, he runs a general shop. He has been in the business for three years and has employed two people. He has witnessed a lot of growth in his business since he joined Faulu Kenya. Francis hopes to open other outlets of his business in five years. He needs to borrow 40,000 Kenya shillings to buy sugar, maize flour, and wheat flour.

loans.use: to buy sugar, maize flour, and wheat flour

loans.name: Lorita

texts.en:
Lorita is 41 years old and lives in Catulayan, San Juan, Siquijor. She is married with three children.

Lorita sells fresh fish every day for a living. Each month, she earns PHP 8,000 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase more fish to sell.

Lorita has been a member of Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative for one month.  Lorita hopes to grow her existing business and be able to support her children who are studying now.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is 46 years old and lives in Macalibre, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is married with one adult-aged child. 

Helen has a shop that sells candles. She has had this business for 15 years. She requested a loan of 20,000 PHP to purchase more boxes of candles to sell.

Helen has been a member of PMPC for 10 years. In the future, Helen hopes to succeed in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more boxes of candles to sell

loans.name: Bumate Kweyimukya Women Group

texts.en: John is a 39-year-old married man with six children living in Bundibugyo, Uganda. His family goal is to educate his children and improve on the living conditions of his family. He is currently running a motorcycle business and this has helped him to provide for his family. His challenge is high fuel costs and his dream is a car. John needs the loan to pay school fees for his children. One of the group members in the photo did not take the loan.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Orsalinda

texts.en:
Orsalinda is 23 years old, married, and blessed with one child. She was only nineteen when she decided to get married. She did not get the opportunity to finish her secondary education because her parents had no capacity to send her to school due to financial problems. Orsalinda wants to prove that not all couples who get married early will always experience financial shortages. Orsalinda is doing her best and helps her husband to uplift their living situation. She wish to send her child to school and give her the opportunity to enter and finish college because she has no other treasure to give other than education.

Orsalinda is managing her hog raising business. She is improving her expertise to be able to grow her business. Orsalinda wants additional piglets to raise but she has no capital to buy them. She decided to borrow a loan of PHP 25,000 to buy additional piglets to raise and feed. She manage her business well and hopes to achieve her wishes.

loans.use: to buy additional piglets to raise and feed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy shoes and a digital camera.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is a businesswoman who sells seeds, fertilizer and animal medicine to earn a living.  She has eight years of experience in this business and has employed one person. Her husband is employed as a civil servant. Previously she was employed as a secretary in a law firm.  

Being a businesswoman she decided to join a group under Faulu Kenya. Through the group, she has opened a savings account and has also been trained on business management. She has requested a loan for 60,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy fertilizer, seeds and animal medicine.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seeds and animal medicine

loans.name: Nicaise

texts.fr:
Client de 47 ans, marie et père de 2 enfants dont l'age varie entre 2 et 27 ans  et a sa charge  5 autres nièces et neveux de sa défunte sœur.
N'ayant pas eu a poursuivre  des longues etudes, il apprend le métier de maçonnerie auprès de son oncle.
Client très exemplaire, il fait preuve des réguliers remboursements et a des épargnes considérables.Étant leader de son groupe, il a bien géré les membres durant les differents cycles, ces differents  crédits lui ont permis  d'atteindre une autonomie financière.
Ce nouveau prêt va lui permettre d'acheter de nouveau 2 tonnes de ciment,16m3 de sable, 12m3 de gravier, des moules, des carreaux et des colorants pour tuiles.
Sa stratégie est de fabriquer  des buses, des latrines turcs, des paves et tous ce dont qu'on utilisent pour la construction.Ces clients sont satisfait de son travail , très serviable il fait la fierté de sa famille .

Dans l'avenir il pense être un grand entrepreneur pour réaliser les grands marches de construction de l'état.
texts.en:
This customer is 47 years old, married and father to two children of eight and 27 years old respectively. He also has five nieces and nephews (his deceased sister's children) in his care. Since he did not pursue his education, he learnt the building trade from his uncle. He is an exemplary customer,  making regular repayments and having considerable savings. He is the leader of his group and has managed the group members well during their various loan cycles, and these loans have allowed him to gain financial autonomy. 

This new loan will enable him to buy two more tons of cement, 16 cubic meters of sand, 12 cubic meters of gravel, molds, tiles and stains for roof tiles. He plans eventually to make pipe culverts, Turkish-style toilets, pavestones and everything that is used for building. These customers are satisfied with his work, he is very helpful and his family is very proud of him. 

He is thinking of one day becoming a significant entrepreneur so that he can undertake large state construction projects.

loans.use: To buy 2 tons ton of cement, 16 cubic meters of sand, iron bars for cement (12) and white cement

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en: Wilson used his previous loan to buy a maize mill. He is a 56-year-old married man and deals in the trade of cereals such as coffee and maize. This has enabled him to provide basics to his family. Wilson needs a loan to buy coffee for sale.

loans.use: to buy coffee.

loans.name: Winfred

texts.en:
Winfred is 34 years old, married, and blessed with two children. To earn a living, She operates a bookstore. She has four years of experience in this business. She also supplies detergents to institutions, particularly to schools. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has learned how to save her money. This has helped her to manage her finances.

Winfred dreams of expanding her business in the future. She has requested for 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy books.

loans.use: To buy books

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a motorcycle for transport.

loans.name: Aiza

texts.en:
Aiza is 23 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 1 child. 

Aiza has a retail shop that sells fish like sardines and mackerel. She has had this business for two years. She requested a loan for 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy fish to sell.

Aiza is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Aiza hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce has practiced farming in the town of Ndunyu Njeru for the last 32 years. She is 54 years old and married to Kuria. They have one school-going child.  

She was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan funds to buy fertilizers and seeds.

In the future, Joyce hopes to expand and improve her farming business and improve her family's living standards.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel's desire is to have a good relationship with her family and to always have faith in our almighty God. Maribel is 22 years old, married, and proud to share that at her age she already has one child. Maribel and her husband work hard to give her child a better future.

Maribel’s husband is a farmer. Aside from farming, Maribel manages a livestock business raising hogs, which serves as an additional source of income for the family. Maribel started this type of business as she knows that it will be a big help to sustain the needs of her family through the profit she earns.

With regards to her livestock business, Maribel is asking for a loan of 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy feed for the maintenance of her pigs. She believes that the loan will be a big contribution to help her maintain her livestock business.

loans.use: to buy feed for the maintenance of her pigs.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 39 years old and married to Saimon. They are blessed with two children who go to school. She is a clothing seller in the area of Kajiando where there is good flow of customers. She has been in this business for the last two years and earns an income of 5,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) per month.

Josephine has a good credit history with KADET and is applying for her second loan of 40,000 KES from KADET LTD. She plans to use the whole amount to purchase more clothes. She will use the anticipated profit to start a wholesale shop.

Josephine hopes to become a wholesaler. She is enterprising and hardworking.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for sale.

loans.name: Damaris

texts.en:
Damaris is 48 years old and married and with four children. She has been operating a retail shop to earn a living. She has been in the business for five years and has employed one person. She also sells charcoal for extra income.  

Through Faulu Kenya, she has been trained on business management. This has helped her to improve the business.

She has requested a loan for for 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian has a shop that sells plant seedlings of different kinds like fruit trees and ordinary trees. She is 35 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with two children. Vivian has had this business for 11 years. She requested a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos to buy additional seedlings to sell.

Vivian has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Vivian hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy additional seedlings to sell.

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 11 years. She is 28 years old. She is married to Joseph, and they have four children.  

She was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers, and this will be her second loan. She repaid her previous loan well and in good time. She plans to use the loan amount to buy fertilizers and seedlings for the next planting season.

In the future, Dorcas hopes to improve her farming skills and become one of the leading farmers in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seedlings.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter has been in the pool business in Naivasha town for the last five years. He is 29 years old and single.

He was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers, and this will be his second loan.  He repaid all of his previous loan well and in good time. He plans to use the loan amount to buy another pool table to add to the one that he has, and thus, be able to accommodate more clients.

In the future, Peter hopes to expand his business and open one of the leading entertainment spots in Naivasha town.

loans.use: To buy a pool table.

loans.name: Rey

texts.en: Rey is 40 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with five children. Rey has a bakeshop that sells snacks and pastries like binangkal and yema, or milk candy. He has had this business for three years. He requested a loan for 8,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to buy raw ingredients for making snacks and pastries. Rey has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Rey hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making snacks and pastries.

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel is a 37-year-old man, married to Martina, a 28-year-old lady. Joel and Martina do not have any children yet, as they just got married at the beginning of this year. Joel and wife are living with his mother temporarily, and he is building his own house next to his mother’s. To make a living, Joel works as a motor taxi driver. He usually works from 6:30 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. delivering customers wherever they want.

Actually, Joel has two motorbikes but one doesn’t work. Joel is planning to repair it so he can generate more income to cover his family's needs and to buy building materials. Unfortunately, Joel does not have the money to do so. Therefore, he would like to request a loan of 3,000,000 Indonesian rupiah to purchase spare parts to repair the motorbike. He hopes that TLM is willing to assist him with a loan.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts and to repair his motorbike

loans.name: Jemima

texts.en:
Jemima has operated her clothing sales business in the town of Nakuru for the last nine years. She is 46 years old and has two children.

She was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers during marketing and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan amount to open up another clothing business.

In the future, Jemima hopes to expand her business and sell new clothes and become one of the leading clothing dealers in Nakuru.

loans.use: to open up another clothing business

loans.name: Ainnie

texts.en:
This is Ainnie, 27, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Fernando, a security guard, and a mother to her two children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating a business. At this time she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Ainnie operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 Philippine pesos (PHP)-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Aside from this she also earns additional income from a room that she offers for rent in her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business she is requesting a loan for 16,000 PHP. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Ainnie hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all of her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for groceries, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Ludivina

texts.en:
Ludivina is 58 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. 

Ludivina has a pigpen that sells grown & matured pigs. She has had this business for 16 years. She requested a loan for 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy animal feed for the pigs.

Ludivina has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Ludivina hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy animal feed for pigs

loans.name: Mary Rose

texts.en:
Mary Rose is 24 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 2 children. 

Mary Rose has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has had this business for 3 years. She requested a loan for 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Mary Rose has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Mary Rose hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Sherly

texts.en:
Sherly is a 44-year-old lady who is married to Leonard, a 49-year-old man. They are blessed with two lovely daughters: Maria, 10, and Katharina, 6. Both are attending elementary school.

Sherly has been running a food stall business for three years. The business is located at an elementary school about 10 meters from her residence.  Sherly sells yellow rice; fried banana, fried tofu, etc to the children at school. She operates the business from 7 am to 1 pm.

Sherly dreams of improving her income by adding a variety of cakes, meals and snacks as demanded by her customers. She is requesting a loan of IDR 3,000,000 from TLM to make her dream come true. She is hoping that TLM will approve her loan application soon.

loans.use: to purchase more snacks and cake ingredients

loans.name: Rechilda

texts.en:
This is Rechilda, 52, a resident of Manila, Philippines. Her husband is Ramon, a market vendor. Rechilda is a mother to her only child. She, together with her husband, manage their household while operating a business. At this time she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Rechilda operates a plastic-ware retail business. What she does is buy plastic-ware products from wholesalers and sell them per item at a profit. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many products that she offered. Her regular customers are neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 700 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan for 25,000 PHP. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Rechilda dreams to be able to give her child a good and high quality education through all of her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for merchandise needed in her business.

loans.name: Sinclair

texts.fr:
Jeune client de 31 ans, celibataire sans enfant , il tient une boutique d'alimentation bientôt 3 ans.
Avec ses differents prêts, il a renforce la capacité de son stock et a fait des remboursements effectifs et a des épargnes considérables et l'impact est très positif en ce qui concerne sa vie financière et sociale.

Avec ce nouveau prêt , il va renforcer le stock de marchandises, acheter des cartons de boites de conserves tel que les macédoines, corne bœuf, des cartons de lait en poudre et du lait concentre.Il a prit un abonnement aupres d'une boulangerie pour  qu'on vienne lui deposer 1000 pains tous les jours.Ses recettes sont de 60.000 frs a 120.000frs par jour.

Tres fier de lui et de ce que Hope est entrain de faire pour sa vie, il continue a épargner et avec ces benefices il a le projet de construire une boutique en matière durable et ajouter a cote un cafeteria
texts.en:
This young, 31-year-old man is single without children. He has been running a grocery store for nearly three years. He used the various loans he obtained to increase his stock. He repaid the loans without problems, and managed to make substantial savings. The experience has had a very positive impact on both his financial situation and his social life. 

He will use this new loan to stock up on merchandise and buy canned goods such as mixed vegetables, corned beef, powdered milk, and condensed milk. He also arranged to have a bakery deliver 1000 loaves of bread daily. 

His sales currently average 60,000 to 120,000 F per day. 

He is very proud of himself, and of what he has achieved with the help of Hope. He will continue to save, and he plans to use his profits to build a shop out of durable materials, with an adjacent cafeteria.

loans.use: to buy canned goods for his grocery store

loans.name: Noime

texts.en:
This is Noime, 41, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Rufo, her business partner, and a mother to her six children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating a business. At this time she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Noime operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 Philippine pesos (PHP)-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan for 50,000 PHP. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Noime hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all of her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en: Gabriel is married and blessed with one child. He describes himself as a hardworking businessman. For the last five years he has been repairing mobile phones and also sells mobile phone spare parts to support his family. In the next five years he wants to expand his business. Gabriel has requested a loan for 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy mobile phone spare parts for resale. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, he has been able to improve his business with his previous loan.

loans.use: to buy mobile phone spare parts.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
This is Evelyn, 58, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Oscar, a side car driver, and a mother of seven children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their household while operating a business. At this time she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Evelyn operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 Philippine pesos (PHP)-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Celia earns a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 1000 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan for 50,000 PHP. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Evelyn dreams to be able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all of her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Stanley

texts.en:
Stanley has been in the clothing business in the town of Naivasha for the last year. He is 42 years old, married to Ruth, and they have three school-going children.

He was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers and this will be his third loan. He paid all of his previous loans well and on time.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy more stock to sell in his business.

In the future, Stanley hopes to expand his business and become one of the leading business people in Naivasha.

loans.use: to add stock to his business

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph used his previous loan to buy seeds and fertilizers. He planted during the planting season. The harvest was very profitable.

This will be his seventh loan and he plans to use the loan amount to buy spraying chemicals and fertilizer for use in this planting season.

In the future, Joseph hopes to improve his farming methods and increase his income, thereby improving the living standards of his family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and chemicals.

loans.name: Dugarmaa

texts.en: Dugarmaa is disabled and a loving mother of two. She lives in the Bulgan province of Mongolia with her husband and two kids. She got into an accident 2 years ago. Since then she always looks for a business opportunity that she is able to do. Now she sews at home and plants flowers for a living. Her brother sells flowers in the market. She is a strong and hardworking woman who says "Even though I am disabled, I have two beautiful kids to support so I can't give up." She is requesting 300,000 Mongolian Tugriks (MNT) to buy sewing materials.

loans.use: to buy sewing materials.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah, 62, is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Wilfredo, a driver, and is the mother of four children. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business.

Sarah operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most families only eat home-cooked meals during the evenings when all family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands costs less than raw food. Sarah's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 700 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Sarah dreams of making her store bigger and hopes to give her family a good future. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies there.

 * All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia, 36, is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Ireneo, a shoe repair man, and is the mother of two children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Delia operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Celia earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 1,000 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP 45,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Delia dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies there.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Munhtsetseg

texts.en:
Munhtsetseg is 50 years old and lives with her husband and two kids in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Bulgan Province, Mongolia. Her husband is an engineer in a mining company, her elder son is a CEO of a small company and the younger one is a clerk in the market. She started her clothes trading business by renting a counter in the local market in 2009. She started her business by retailing Chinese products now she retails Korean products as well. 

Now customers want more high quality expensive products and she needs to meet the customers' demand in order to keep up with them. She is a sharp and hardworking woman who says "I have done everything I can to support my kids. Now that they are old enough, it is time to expand my business". She is requesting a 1,600,000 MNT loan to buy more clothes.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Albertine

texts.fr:
Cliente de 51 ans, celibataire avec 3 enfants dont l'age varie entre 22 et 33 ans.A l'obtention de son diplôme comme agent de sante, n'ayant pas pu trouver du travail , elle se lance dans la vente de bois, il y'a bientôt 23 ans.
Étant bénéficiaire de Hope bientôt une année, ces differents prêts ont largement contribue a l'épanouissement spirituelle,financière et sociale de sa famille, Elle est parmi les clientes qui épargne le plus et  elle a des remboursements effectives  sans défauts de paiements quelque soit le temps.

Avec ce nouveau prêt , elle va renforcer le stock de son stock de prêt , elle a une capacité de vente de 2000 fagots par mois. Ces clients sont les restaurateurs qui font des grillades, des beignets et les ménagères de son quartier et les environs. 

Tres populaire dans le quartier, tout le monde parle d'elle et ses ambitions sont entrain de se réaliser petit a petit, elle a fini a construire sa maison dans la parcelle familiale et elle épargne avec ses benefices , elle est entrain de penser d'associer au bois la vente du manioc et ouvrir un dépôt de poissons sales.
texts.en:
This client is 51 years old, and is single with 3 children whose ages vary from 22 to 33 years. After getting her degree as a health agent, she could not find a job so she started selling wood about 23 years ago. 
Having been a HOPE borrower since about a year ago, her different loans have made significant contributions to her spiritual, financial and social growth, and that of her family. She is among the clients who saves the most and repays correctly without lateness no matter the time.
With this new loan, she will purchase new stock. She can sell up to 2000 pieces of wood per month. Her clients are the restaurants which grill food or make fried dough, and households in and around her neighborhood.
Very popular in her neighborhood, everyone talks about her and her ambitions are being realized, little by little. She finished building her house on her family's land and is saving with her profits. She is thinking of adding manioc-selling to her existing wood-selling business, and to open a dried fish-selling store.

loans.use: Sale of firewood and charcoal

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana is widowed and blessed with two children. She has been selling goats for the last 13 years to support her family. She also does farming to supplement her income. In the next five years, she wants to expand her business. She has requested a loan of 10,000 Kenyan shillings to buy goats for resale.

loans.use: To buy  goats.to sell

loans.name: Daouda

texts.fr:
Mr DAOUDA   est marié et Père de 01 enfant. Il a 02ans et personne ne va à l’école. Il a 04 personnes en charge.

Mr est couturier  depuis 09ans. Il s’approvisionne au  marché de toecin (secteur 20 Ouaga). Ses clients sont les femmes, les hommes et les enfants.

Il veut  s’acheter  220m de tissus pour doublure, 10m de tissus pour double col, 03 sachets de boutons, 10 paquets de dentelles, 02 paquets d’aiguilles, 36 fermetures, 10 paquets de fils à coudre et 10m de tissus satin.

Mr  utilise ses bénéfices pour  améliorer les conditions de travaille en achetant d’autres machines et accessoires. Il  ambitionne  ouvrir une boutique pour vendre les accessoires de couture (mercerie) tout en assurant sa couture et améliorer les conditions de vie des membres de sa famille en assurant leur santé, éducation et leur alimentation.
texts.en: Mr Daouda is married and the father of a two year old child, who does not attend school. He is responsible for four persons. He has been a tailor/seamster for the past 9 years, sewing clothes for women, men and children. He stocks up on cloth at the Toecin market (near Ouaga). He is asking for this loan in order to purchase 220m of cloth for lining, 10m of cloth for double collars, 3 packs of buttons, 10 packs of lace, 2 packets of needles, 36 zippers, 10 packets of sewing thread and 10m of satin. Profits from these sales will be used to improve his working conditions, through the purchase of machines and accessories. In the future, he would like to open a store in order to sell sewing accessories in addition to continuing his sewing business, in order to improve the living conditions of his family and covering their health, education and nutrition expenses.

loans.use: purchase 230m of cloth for sewing, 3 packets of buttons, 10 packets of lace, 2 packets of needles, 36 zippers, 10 packets of sewing thread and 10m of satin

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy maize and beans to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sugar and rice.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert is married and blessed with two children who are in school. He describes himself as a hardworking businessman. He has been operating a meat supplier business, where he uses his motorbike for the transportation of meat to support his family. He has been in the business for the last 11 years. He has been able to retain his business because of his good reputation with his customers. Robert has requested a loan of 20,000  Kenyan shillings to buy a cow to slaughter.

loans.use: To buy a cow to slaughter.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia is single and blessed with four children. She describes herself as a hardworking businesslady. She has been running a grocery for the last 11 years to support her family. She also runs a beauty salon to supplement her income. In the next five years, she wants to expand her business. She has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy potatoes, vegetables and tomatoes for resale.

loans.use: To buy potatoes, vegetables and tomatoes.

loans.name: George

texts.en: George is a hardworking businessman aged 33. He is married and blessed with two children, one of whom is in school. He has been involved with a business of hiring tents for the last three years to bring up his family. He has employed two people to assist him to manage the business. George has been able to retain his business because of his good reputation with his customers. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to access loans to boost his business. In the next five years, he wants to expand his business. He has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more seats for the tents.

loans.use: To buy more seats for the tents.

loans.name: Demur

texts.en:
Demur is 69 years old. He lives in the village Dzevri, Imereti Region, West Georgia. Demur is married and lives with his family: his wife, Rusiko, and his 32-year-old son. Demur is a blacksmith. He has a small workshop and performs different orders for the villagers. His son is a worker-constructor; Rusiko is actively involved in family agriculture. 

The family has two milk cows; they sell dairy products in the village. Also the family owns 0.8 hectares of land, where maize is grown. Demur and Rusiko use part of the harvested maize to feed the cows and the other part is sold locally. The total average monthly income of the family is 450 Laris. 

Demur has requested credit to purchase additional agricultural land. He will cultivate it and sow additional maize. The family will get more corn for sale and thus increase their income. Demur and Rusiko will use the additional income to improve the family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural land

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Paulina is a hardworking businesswoman aged 58. She is married and blessed with six children, one of whom is in school. For the last 32 years, she has been running a cereal shop to bring up her family. She also sells charcoal to increase her income. She has employed one person to assist her to manage the business. Paulina has been able to retain her business because of her good reputation with her customers. In the next five years, she plans to establish a wholesale business. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to access loans to boost her business. Paulina has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy maize and beans for resale.

loans.use: To buy maize and beans.

loans.name: Eter

texts.en:
Eter is from the village Zeda Sazano, West Georgia. She is 61 years old. Eter lives alone. She earns her living through agricultural activities. In particular, she owns two milk cows. She uses milk for cheese production and sells cheese in the village. Along with the dairy farm, Eter owns one hectare of land of which 0.4 hectare is used for maize growing. On the remaining 0.6 hectares of land, Eter grows vines. She sells harvested maize and grapes locally in the village. Her total average income is 180 Laris per month. 

Although Eter works hard during the whole day, her income is still not enough to save money for house renovation. Her house is already old, in bad condition and needs renovation. Eter has requested credit for the renovation of her house. This will allow her to improve her living conditions and enjoy a well-deserved rest in the evening hours, after hard work during the daytime.

loans.use: to purchase materials for house renovation

loans.name: Maurice

texts.en: Maurice is a hardworking businessman aged 41. He is married and blessed with seven children all of whom attend school. He has been operating a motorbike transport business for the last two years to support his family. He also does farming to supplement his income. He runs his business in a very competitive environment but he is able to retain his customers because of his good reputation. In the next five years, he wants to expand his farming business. Maurice is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy fertilizer and seeds for his farm.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds.

loans.name: Saint Jean Baptiste Group

texts.fr:
Mme ODETTE est la représentante du groupe SAINT JEAN BAPTISTE .Elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants. Le plus âgé a 23ans et le moins âgé a 06ans. 03 vont à l’école. Elle a 05 personnes en charge.

Elle prépare et vend le dolo  depuis 12ans. Elle s’approvisionne au  marché de Bendatoega village environnant. Ses clients sont les femmes et les  hommes.

Elle veut  s’acheter  02sacs et demi de sorgho rouge pour la préparation de son dolo.

Mme épargne et améliore les conditions de vie de sa famille avec ses bénéfices. Elle ambitionne augmenter sa production et acheter un motocycle.
texts.en:
Mrs. Odette is the representative for the Saint Jean Baptiste group. She is married and has six children. Her oldest is 23, and the youngest is 6. Three of them are attending school. She has five of them in her care.

She has been making and selling dolo (a type of beer) for 12 years. She buys her supplies at the nearby Bendatoega village market. Her customers are comprised of men and women. 

She wants to buy 2.5 sacks of red sorghum to make her dolo.

She is saving money and improving her family's living conditions with her profits. She would like to increase her production and buy a motorbike.

loans.use: to buy 2.5 sacks of red sorghum for making dolo.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is married and blessed with one child who is in school. She has been running a beauty salon for the last 11 years to support her family. She has employed two people to assist her to manage the business. In the next five years, she wants to open another outlet of her business. Mary dreams of buying a piece of land and building rental houses in future. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to access loans to boost her business. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy a hairdrier and a blow dry machine.

loans.use: To buy a hairdrier and a blow dry machine.

loans.name: Murman

texts.en:
Murman is from the village Siktarva, West Georgia. He is 51 years old, married and lives with his wife, Shorena, and his 28-year-old daughter. The family is busy with agriculture and trade. They own two milk cows. Shorena produces cheese and sells it at the local open market. Also they own a small grocery store in the village. Murman spends most of his time in the store. He purchases grocery products in a nearby town and sells them in his store. 

Murman has requested credit to increase his trading stock in the store. He will beat the competitors with an increased assortment of products, attracting new customers. It will allow Murman to increase his sales and raise the family's profits. The additional income will allow family members to purchase needed household goods and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to increase his trading stock in a village grocery store

loans.name: Bulala Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Bulala Group in Western Kenya! Mary is the facilitator of the Bulala group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. Like the majority of people in this part of Kenya, the members of Bulala Group are farmers who rely on maize for annual food security and income.

Mary takes care of eight children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Mary had an excellent maize yield harvesting 17 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Mary was only able to harvest two bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Mary and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Mary will invest in livestock rearing, and buy a motorbike in order to begin a taxi business.

In 2012, the members of Bulala group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

She is pictured in the photograph with her group members

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Ivan

texts.ru:
Иван работает на одном из продуктовых рынков Ивано-Франковска. Раньше он работал на кирпичном заводе, но после закрытия предприятия был вынужден пойти работать на рынок. На данный момент Иван торгует овощами, а именно картошкой, огурцами, помидорами, луком, а также сезонными и несезонными фруктами, цитрусовыми, а зимой еще и рыбой. Он всегда предоставляет большой ассортимент фруктов и овощей по низким ценам, к тому же на этом базарчике мало конкурентов с аналогичным видом товара. Иван занимается реализацией продуктов уже на протяжении 4 лет. Его ежемесячный доход составляет 7 000 гривен. 

Раньше базарчик, на котором торговал Иван, был стихийным. Но недавно местные власти решили узаконить и облагородить этот рынок, вследствие чего там стали строить аккуратные киоски-будки, каждый из которых стоит 25 000 гривен. Иван хотел бы вложить средства, полученные от КИВА, в приобретение нового торгового киоска. Ему в ближайшее время необходимо внести первый взнос за киоск. Иван сам планирует торговать в новом киоске, а в прежнем, который будет перемещен в другое место, будет торговать его жена. В результате этого расширения Иван надеется, что его торговля увеличится в 1.5-2 раза. В будущем Иван хотел бы приобрести автомобиль, что становится все больше и больше актуально и для ведения бизнеса.  

Пометка: история на русском языке
texts.en: Ivan works at one of the produce markets in Ivano-Frankivsk.  He previously worked at a brick factory, but was forced to find work at the market after the factory closed down.  Currently, Ivan sells vegetables, such as potatoes, cucumbers, tomatoes, onions and also seasonal and nonseasonal fruits, citrus fruits, and also fish in the winter.  He always offers a wide variety of fruits and vegetables at low prices, and besides, there are not many competitors with similar products at the market.  Ivan has been involved in selling products for four years.  His monthly income is 7,000 hryvnia.  Previously, this market, where Ivan works, was disastrous.  Recently, however, local government decided to legalize and beautify this market and subsequently started to build neat kiosks-booths, each one of which costing 25,000 hryvnia.  Ivan wants to invest the money, received from Kiva, into the purchase of a new retail kiosk.  He needs to pay his first installment for the kiosk soon.  Ivan plans to work in the new kiosk, and his wife would work in the old kiosk, which will be relocated elsewhere.  As a result of this expansion, Ivan hopes that his sales will increase by 1.5-2 times.  In the future, Ivan wants to purchase a car, which is becoming more and more necessary for running the business.

loans.use: to purchase a new kiosk

loans.name: Loise

texts.en:
Loise is 54 years old, married and they are blessed with three children.

She is a greengrocer in the area of Kakuyuni where there is a good flow of customers. She has been in this business for the last four years and earns an income of KES 11,000 per month.

Loise has a good credit history with KADET. She is applying for her fifth loan of KES 30,000 from KADET LTD with which she plans to buy cereals like maize and beans. She will use the anticipated profit to pay school fees.

Loise is very hardworking and hopes to own her own cereal threshing board.

loans.use: To buy cereals.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy pigs.

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.ru:
Людмила – из небольшого поселка Веселое. Она – вдова, сама воспитала двух сыновей – Андрея и Павла. У Людмилы есть небольшой магазинчик «Темп» на центральном рынке поселка. Там она торгует автозапчастями, канцелярскими товарами, а также предоставляет услуги фотоателье и ксерокопирования. Этот бизнес Людмила открыла еще в 2003. С тех пор ее оборотный капитал вырос до 21 000 гривен, а прибыль составляет 7 000 гривен. 

Людмила надеется вложить кредит КИВА в 10 000 гривен в закупку товара и приобретение нового принтера для фотопечати. Ей нравится это направление, и она уверенно считает его самым приемлемым для себя и своего поселка. За счет получения дополнительной прибыли от ведения бизнеса Людмила планирует сделать ремонт в доме, что было необходимо сделать уже давно.
